LXXV. Sir William Throckmorton, Richard Berkeley, et al. "ORDINANCES DIRECTIONS AND INSTRUCTIONS TO CAPTAINE JOHN WOODLEFE"

SEPTEMBER 4, 1619

Smyth of Nibley Papers, Smyth, 10, also 3 (6), pp. 61-63 Document in the New York Public Library List of Records No. 126

Ordinances directions and Instructions to Captaine John Woodleefe for the government of our men and servants in the Towne and hundred of Bearkley in Virginia given by us Sr. William Throckmorton knight and baronet Richard Berkeley Esq, George Thorpe esq, and John Smyth gent wherevnto our commission of the date hereof made to the said captaine Woodleefe hath reference, the fourth day of September 1619 Anno xvij° Jac. regis Angli & 1

Imprimis wee ordaine that the day of our ships arrivall at the place assigned for plantation in the land of Virginia shall be yearly and perpetually keept holy as a day of thanksgiving to Almighty God.
1487:
208 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

2. Wee doe ordaine that the lord's day be keept in holy and religious order and that all bodily labour and vaine sporte and scandalous recreations be refrained, and that morning and evening prayer (according to the English booke of common prayer) be Dayly read and attended vnto and such other divine exercises of preaching and reading to be on the said day vsed, as it shall please God to enable the minister for the tyme there being to performe. And that all such other festivalls and holidayes be observed and keept wch are authorised and appoynted by the lawes and statutes of this realme of England, And the rites and ceremonies authorized, prescribed or apoynted by the ecclesiasticall lawes or cannons of this realme of England and booke of common prayer (established by authority) be in all things observed and keept, according as it is vsed in the church of England.

3. Wee doe ordayne and direct, that you our gouernor and all our people and servants assemble together once a day to prayer, imediatly after the forenoone labour ended and before dinner. And that the person then absent (you our gouernor and your assistants hereafter named excepted) shalbe punished with the losse of his supper the same evening vnles the minister or you selfe allowe of his excuse or cause of his absence.

4. Wee will and require that vpon your arrivall in the kings river in Virginia or in any branch thereof that you take especiall care for choice of the place where you first sett downe and entend for your settled habitation, (be it on this side or beyond James [MARGINAL NOTE: towne]) that the same be healthy for ayre and accomodate with fresh water and easy for accesse vnto with shipe pinnace or barge rich alsoe in mould and [MARGINAL NOTE: soyle] and of most likelyhoode to bring forth the best commodities of that cuntry either already knowne or by vs hoped for, And iron oare silke grasse mulbery trees for norishing of silke wormes, apt for vines, English wheat, maize and other Virginia corne and for rice, Aniseeds flax [MARGINAL NOTE: oade] oyle seede and the like, rich alsoe in meadow and pasture for cattell and in timber for shiping and other vses, and alsoe convenient and vsefull for fowle fish and the like, And that you resolve not on the place without the advice of your assistants hereafter named and the assent of the greater number of them, Wherein alsoe wee will you to proceed with the advice of Sr. George Yardley gouernor of that kingdome, deliuering our letters written.
1488:
SEPTEMBER 4, 1619

209

vnto him in that behalfe, provided that you settle not but where the natiues, (if any be or clayme) are first avoyded by composition.

5. Wee doe ordayne and direct that imediatly after the place of habitation is agreed vppon in manner aforesaid, that yoᵘ cause forthwᵗʰ to be erected houses fit for the present shelter and succor of our people wᶜʰ as wee suppose, may be for the better expedition built homelike and to be couered wᵗʰ bordes; of wᶜʰ we commend to yoʳ especiall care the framing of twoo, whereof the one for the safe keeping of the tooles, implements of husbandry, powder, shott, Armor, and victuall, wᶜʰ wee wish may be strongly planted on the inside: And the other for your assemblies at time of prayer and time of diet, and our further direction is, That if the ship shall disburden for lading before the said storehouses for receipt thereof can be built, That then the same be vnladen into the comon warehouse in James Towne, or the Bermuday granary by the gouernors order and therevnto first obtayned.

6. Wee doe ordaine that wᵗʰ all convenient expedition, yoᵘ cause to be inclosed 400 acres (or more) wᵗʰ a stronge pale of seaven foote and halfe highe whereby such corne grayne seede vines Tobacco, and the like as shalbe sowen or planted and such cattle as shalbe transported by vs or provided in Virginia, will be more safely preserved.

7. Wee doe nominate and commend vnto yoᵘ as yoᵘ assistantes for yoʳ better execution of the authority by vs on yoᵘ conferred, Ferdinando Yeat, John Blanchard, Richard Godfry, Rowland Panter, and Thomas Coppy, of whose seuerall integrities and discretions wee hauing made sufficient triall doe therefore ordaine, that in all businesses of import of what kind soever, you take their advise, and the assent of the greatest part of them fiue: And that they diet wᵗʰ and as yoʳ selfe, at one and the same table togeather. And that alsoe all the rest doe diet togeather, and to be equaly provided for as nere as may be:

8. We doe ordaine, that there shalbe an ordinary Corps de garde each night in our towne of Bearkley, to consist at the first of fiue, to succeede in turne as the company will afford and afterwards as yoᵘ number shall encrease whereof one to be of the number of those seaven that shall be deputie and called, captaines of the watche.
1489:
210 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

9 I for the more decent and comely gouerment and ordering of our family wee substitute and appoynt, Ferdinando Yeat to be ancient, and Rowland Paynter Sergeant of the company, And John Blanchard to be steward of the household and clarke of the store of apparrell and beding And the said Rowland Paynter to be clarke of the kitchin, with two or more (as Caters or country Purvires) to be associated vnto him, And Henry Perce to be vsher of the hall and Thomas Partridg now abiding in Virginia (if he ioyne vnto to be balyffe of our husbandries, if not, then whome you and your assistant shall thinke meete, and the said Ferdinando Yeat to take care of our Armor and of all our tooles of husbandry.

10 I wee doe ordayne that if it shall soe please God that Mr. Woodleefe dye before the Arivall of Mr. Chester, That then the gouerment of our families and of our affayres shall remaine with and vnder those Assistant and the survivers of them that wee haue before associated vnto Mr. Woodleefe and if it shall please God that either Mr. Woodleefe or Mr. Chester shall die after both of them are arrived in Virginia, That then the gouerment of both families shall remaine with and vnder the surviver of them ayded with the assistante of both families.

[Indorsed:] Copy of Instructions geven to Captayne Woodleefe. 4. Sept. 1619. 17. Jac.

LXXVI. INDENTURE BETWEEN THE FOUR ADVENTURERS OF BERKELEY HUNDRED AND ROBERT COOPY OF NORTH NIBLEY

SEPTEMBER 7, 1619

Smyth of Nibley Papers, Smyth, 11 Document in the New York Public Library. Original Document with Signatures and Seals Affixed List of Records No. 127

This Indenture made the seventh day of September. 1619. in the xvijth yeare of the raigne of our soueraigne lord kinge James of England &c. Betwene Sr. William Throkmorton knight and baronet Richard Berkley Esq, George Thorpe Esq, and Iohn Smyth gent on the one pte And Robert Coopy of Northnibly in the county of Glouc Husbandman on th’other pte. Witnesseth That the said Robert doth hereby covenant
1490:
SEPTEMBER 7, 1619

...faithfully to serve the said Sr. William, Richard, George and John for three yeares from date hereof his landing in the land of Virginia, there to be employed in the lawfull and reasonable workes and labors of them the said Sr. William, Richard, George and John and their assignes, and to be obedient to such governors, his and their assistants and counsell as they the said Sr. William, Richard, George and John shall from tyme to tyme appoint and set over him. In consideration whereof, the said Sr. William, Richard, George and John doe covenant with the said Robert to transport him (with God's assistance) with all convenient speed into the said land of Virginia at their cost and charges in all things, and there to maintain him with convenient diet and apparel meet for such a servant, And in the end of the said terme to make him a free man of the said Country thereby to enjoy all the liberties, freedoms and privileges of a freeman there, And to grant to the said Robert thirty acres of land within their Territory or hundred of Barkley in the said land for the terme of his life and of two others then by him to be named (if he be then living) under the yearly rent of twelve pence for each acre, and such other reasonable conditions and services as are usuall and accustomed in the said land. Set or before the sealing thereof shall be agreed between the said parties. And to pay each quarter of a yeare ten shillings to the wife of the said Robert at her house in North-nibly aforesaid towards her maintenance during the said terme if he so long live, Whereof is already paid thirty shillings. Given interchangeably under their hands and seales the day and yeare first above written.

Ric: BERKELEY (Seal)  
Geo: THORPE (Seal)  
Iohn SMYTH (Seal)

LXVII. Sir William THROCKMORTON AND HIS THREE ASSOCIATES Letter To Sir GEORGE YEARDLEY SEPTEMBER 9, 1619 Smyth of Nibley Papers, Smyth, 3 (11), Page 77 Document in the New York Public Library List of Records No. 128

[77] To our honorable frend Sr. George Yardley knight governor of Virginia. Hof Sr: Wee send here inclosed the copy of our Ire written the xviijth of February last, least the same should not yet bee come to your hands, And although we have somewhat longer drawne out the dispatch of our busines by reason of some hindrances that vnexpectedly arose, yet by gods assistance we have herewith sent in a ship called the Margaret of Bristoll 35 men vnder the comaund of Captayne Iohn Woodleefe to bee planted in Virginia by vertue of our Patent, wherin if it please you to hold a pte, wee need not doubt of your assistance; but not knowinge whether your other nowe greater imploymt will suffer you to discend soe lowe as to accept hereof, wee doe hereby comend vnto your favorable ptection our wholl busines, aswell for the choyce of a fit place for our plantaton (wth in pticular we leave to Captayne Woodleefe to informe) as also to comend vnto you the desire wee your frends have to live in the favorable remembrance of your dayly assistinge of Captayne Woodleefe: Wee also send you herewith the Accompt of all charges past in this busines, that you may the better satisfy yourselfe, whether you will bee pleased to Ioyne with vs or noe, intreatinge that if you shall accept of our ptnership, That then by this ship you send vs either in mony or mchantable goods your fifth pte therof, and also order for the charges of further supply to bee sent vnto our plantaton both of men & neces- saries wch by gods assistance wee purpose not longer to neglect, then Aprill next at the farthest. The further adutisement of our affayres we comend to the relacon of Captayne Woodleefe. Comendinge our- selves in all frendly respects, We remayne ever Your very loving frends

Wittm THROKMORTON Richard BERKELEY George THORPE Bristoll 9. Sept 1619 John SMYTHE

LXXX. Sir Edwin Sandys. A Letter to John Ferrar

SEPTEMBER 20, 1619

Ferrar Papers Document in Magdalene College, Cambridge University. Autograph Letter, Signed List of Records No. 131

Sr I send you here enough to read; & therefore my owne writing may be short: so also must it be, for my tyme is spent. The next week I will write to you at full of all busines, & the next moneth be with you, to assist in effecting them. Meane while I shalbe glad to heare from you of the news stirring in those parts: especially of the certainty of the affaires of Bohemia: & what else you please.

I pray you doo not swarue from my former order of paiments: viz First all for the Bona nova. Secondly Fraight & wages for the Diana. Thirdly the old Debts for the Diana: coming by Mr. Webs note to 170l in all. Then not anie more till our meeting, for a reason you then shall knowe.

And I pray you get the warrents to me for all from the Committies: & to beare Date a little before the monie was paid: hereof be carefull: But for the old Debt for the Diana it must be from the Auditors. So with most hartie commendacions, I rest

Your assured, Edwin Sandys

Northborn. 20. September: 1619.

LXXXI. Sir Edwin Sandys. A LETTER To THE [Earl of SOUTHAMPTON] SEPTEMBER 29, 1619

Ferrar Papers Document in Magdalene College, Cambridge University. A Rough Draft in Sandys’ Autograph List of Records No. 132

[1] Right Honorable

Being advertized of your Lordship's return to London, it troubled me much that I could not suddenly wait upon your Lordship: being detained here by a course of physick, imposed upon me for some time, yet; in way of prevention. I am also put in some hope & expectance, that my Lord of Doncaster will be pleased to take my house in his way: at which time I should be exceedingly loth to be absent, being so much beholden to his Lordship as I am. Meantime I am, & have been careful, that there should be no neglect found in our Virginia business. The chief whereof is now, the paying of mariners' wages, & freight of Ships returned: which is all well performed by my honest, faithful & careful Deputy; whom I have furnished for that purpose with above One Thousand pounds & upward; so that all men have been satisfied justly at their days. Only one thing doth much perplex me, wherein I shall be bold to crave some Direction from your Lordship. The Governor Sr George Yeardley, having taken exceeding pains for the settling of all matters in order in Virginia, & for laying the foundation of a regular State, according to his Instructions & other Directions; hath suddenly fallen into a violent resolution of quitting his Place, (grounding himself upon an error,) & ceaseth not by all his letters public & private to importune it. The error is, that he conceiveth Sr Thomas Smyth still to be Treasurer, with his Alderman Deputy: & supposeth that he shall be there.
1496: SEPTEMBER 29, 1619 217 the Subiect of their malignancie, & so as to be wronged & disgraced by them in his place & actions (be his Industrie & Integritie never so great) Sr. Th. Smyth was highly offended with his (Sir George Yeardley's being) knighted: aleging that (it) being doon contrarie to his pleasure, yet both his name; & the whole companies name, were used in it (either) whereof [in truth] was so. Before Sr. Georges Departure, I both labored & effected a Reconciliation, (thinking it very unfitt that the Treasurer of the Companie, & the Governor of the Colonie, should be at Variance: & mutual offices of love (& frendship) & adres did passt on bothe sides. After Sr. Georges (was gone) departure; I (perceived) my woork to be unsound. For upon occasion of a motion made openly against Sr. G. Yeardley by a noble person in favor as (contemplation as seemed) was conceived of Captain Argall, Sr. Thomas taking the advantage renewed his former [24] displeasure; not long after upbraiding again in open court his unduely procured Knighthood: Mr. Canning also muttering matter of disgrace by (to) his wife: & this against a man, to whom they (had) professed frendship, (who was) chosen by themselves, & sent (by them in great part at his own private charges) to so difficult a service. The report hereof coming (as dooth now appeare) to Sr. G. Yeardley, (for his owne brother was present), hath bred in him this discontent, & hastie resolution, not to serve under his controll, whose hatred (though causeles) was so strong, as to break thorough the (nue) bounds of a publick reconciliation. Yet he offereth, that being dismissed of the place of Governor, he will continue in that Contrie, & prosecute with all care of Smiths Hundred busines. Which in particular for our Societie were a matter of much benefit: but the well carrying of the publick is of more importance. To the setting up whereof, we have this yeare alredy sent three Fifties of persons: One in Januarie with Sr. G. Yeardley, for the Governor's land: & the other two now lately, for the College & Companies lands. There were also in March last 20. sent for the Companies land in Captain Lawns Ship: & 4. in the Triall: & about 10. more for the publick will be recovered in the Contrie. My Desire is to make those Fifties up so manie Hundreds, to be sent away in the end of Januarie next. To which purpose I cast about for supplie of monie: & am in good hope to bring it to effect. I suppose there is no man that knoweth the Contrie, but will easily acknowledge, that the profit of the labors of these three hundred men (once setled), redounding equally.
1497: 218 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY to the Governour, College, & Companie, can be esteemed at no lesse then a Thousand pounds a yeare to each; & I hope in som short tyme double that sum. wᵗʰ wilbe a fair ground whereon to reedifie that state: & wᵗʰ, if former my persuasions had taken anie place, had not been now to doo for the Governoᵘʳ & Companie. But this my good L. cannot be doon wᵗʰout great charge. wᶜʰ causeth the wᵗʰdrawing of publick monie out of private mens hands: whence riseth this name of Accounts, so mortally hated. I had thought that no man, carrying the face of an honest man, could have been displeased wᵗʰ beeing called to an Account: beeing the onlie iustification & discharge of a true man. But it hath fallen out otherwise. In steed of thanks for my laboᵘʳ, I have reaped a masse of malignitie: under wᶜʰ (had it not been by the help of yoᵘʳ Lᵖˢ noble Justice) I might have quailed. But in affiance of the blessing of God first & next of the continuance of yᵉ Lᵖˢ Constancie good favor, I will not faint in persisting to goo on to dooime that, wᵗʰout wᶜʰ this woork can not be doon. But touching St George Yeardley, the assurance wᶜʰ I gave of his faithfulnes, experience, honest care, sufficiencie & industrie, dooth cause me much to desire it exceedingly that the woork wᶜʰ in my yeare dooth moove from hence, may passe on unto under to his hands to be the establing of there established of it there: Men of greater place or higher thoughts may perhaps folde their owne particular mynds: wᶜʰ heretofore I doubt hath doon little good to the Colonie. Besides I hold fit that no mutation be made, till Sʳ Thomas Dales return: that we may first knowe what coorse he then entends to wi take. Sʳ George Yeardley hath written of late twice to the Counseil, once by the Diana, & as wᶜʰ came to my hands; & since by the Prosperous, wᶜʰ are delivered to Sʳ Thomas Smith. The former packett I opened, having present oportunitie to write back unto him: & now have sent it to oᵘʳ Deputie Mʳ Ferrar, to be presented to yᵉ Lᵖ wᶜʰ the rest of the Counseil, when yᵉ Lᵖ shall be pleased that they be assembled. My humble suit to yᵉ L is, enks for the if it shall seem good of Virginia for the service of Virginia no advantage be taken of Sʳ Georges rash offer ever (nethine dewtine but conceiving that by this tyme seeing his erroʳ he would recall it,) he could: but that either it may be passed elene over in silence, or reserved held in suspence till som farther oportunitie may better discover what is fittest.
1498:
SEPTEMBER 30, 1619

to be doon. About Alholantyde, not to faile if God permit, I purpose to present my personall service to your Lordship. Meane while my best prayers shall alwaies thether ascend, whence I beseech that all best blessings may descend upon your Lordship. And so with all duetie I take humble leave & rest

[No signature.]

Northborn 29. Sept. 1619.

[Indorsed by Sir Edwin Sandys:] From Sr. Edw. Sandis dated the 29 Sept: 1619. [No address.]

LXXXII. John Pory. A Letter to "the Right Honble and my singular good Lorde"

SEPTEMBER 30, 1619

Barlow Collection, 2270 Document in the New York Public Library. Autograph Letter, Signed List of Records No. 133

Right honorable and my singular good lorde,

Hauing mett with so fitt a messenger as this man of warre of Flushing, I could not but imparte with your lordship (to whom I am so euerlastingly bounde) these poore fruites of our labours here; wherein though your lordship will espie many errours & imperfections, and matters of lowe esteeme; yet withall you wilbe contente to obserue the very principle and rudiments of our Infant-Comonwealth; which though nowe contemptible, your lordship may liue to see a flourishing Estate; maugre both Spaniards & Indians. The occasion of this ships coming hither was an accidental consortship in the West Indies with the Treasurer an English man of warre also, licensed by a Commission from the Duke of Sauoye to take Spaniards as lawfull prize. This ship the Treasurer wente out of England in Aprill was tweluemoneth, about a moneth, I thinke, before any peace was concluded between the king of Spaine & that prince. Hither shee came to Captaine Argall then governour of this Colony, being parte-owner of her. Hee more for loue of gaine the root of all euill, [...] then for any true love he bore to this Plantation, victualled & manned her anewe, and sente her with the same Commission to raunge the Indies. The euente whereof (we may misdoubte) will proove some
1499:
220 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

attempt of the Spaniard upon us, either by way of revenge, or by way of prevention; least we might in time make this place sedem belli against the West Indies. But our Governour being a soldier truly bred in that university of warre the lowe Countries, purposeth at a place or two upon the river fortifiable to provide for them, animating in the meane while this warlike people (than whom for their small number, no prince can be served wth better) by his example to prepare their courages. Both those of our nation and the Indians also have this Torride sommer bene visited wth great sicknes & mortality; wch our good God (his name be blessed for it) hath recompensed wth a maruelous plenty, such as hath not bene seen since our first coming into the land. For my selfe I was partly at land & partly at sea vexed wth a Calenture of some 4. or 5. months. But (praised be God) I am nowe as healthfull as ever I was in my life. Here (as yo lo? cannot be ignorant) I am, for fault of a better, Secretary of Estate, the first that ever was chosen and appointed by Commission from the Counsell and Company in England, under their handes & common seale. By my fees I must maintain my selfe; wch the Governour tells me, may this yeare amount to a matter of 300£ sterling; whereof fifty I doe owe to himselfe, and I pray God the remainder may amount to a hundred more. As yet I have gotten nothing, save only (if I may speak it wout boasting) a general reputation of integrity, for having spoken freely to all matters, according to my conscience; and as near as I could discern, done every man right.

As touching the quality of this country, three things there be, wch in few years may bring this Colony to perfection; the English plough, Vineyards, & Cattle. For the first, there be many grounds here cleared by the Indians to our handes, wch being much worn out, will bear no more of their corn, wch requireth an extraordinary deal of sap & substance to nourish it: but of our grain of all sorts it will bear great abundance. We have had this year a plentiful crop of English wheat, tho the last harvest 1618. was only shed upon the stubble, and so self-sown, wout any other manurance. In July last so soon as we had reaped this self-sown wheat, we set Indian corn upon the same ground, wch is come up in great abundance; and so by this means we are to enjoy two crops in one year from off one & the same field. The
1500:
SEPTEMBER 30, 1619

The greatest labour we haue yet bestowed upon English wheate, hath bene, upon newe broken up groundes, one ploughing onely & one harrowing, far shorte of the Tilthe used in Christendome, wch when we shall haue ability enough to performe we shall produce miracles out of this earthe. Vines here are in suche abundance, as wheresoeuer a man treads, they are ready to embrace his foote. I haue tasted here of a great black grape as big as a Damascin, that hath a true Muscatell-taste; the vine wherof now spending itselfe euen to the topps of high trees, if it were reduced into a vineyard, and there domesticated, would yeild incomparable fruite. The like or a better taste haue I founde in a lesser sorte of black grapes. White grapes also of great excellency I haue hearde to be in the country; but they are very rare, nor did I euer see or taste of them. For cattle, they do mightily increase here, both kine, hogges, & goates, and are much greater in stature, then the race of them first brought out of England. No lesse are our horses and mares likely to multiply, wch proove of a delicate shape, & of as good spirite & metall. All our riches for the present doe consiste in Tobacco, wherein one man by his owne labour hath in one yeare, raised to himselfe to the value of 200 li sterling; and another by the meanes of sixe seruants hath cleared at one crop a thousand pound english. These be true, yet indeed rare examples, yet possible to be done by others. Our principall wealth (I should haue said) consisteth in seruants: but they are chardgeable to be furnished wth armes, apparell, & bedding, and for their transportation, and casuall both at sea, & for their first yeare commonly at lande also: but if they escape, they prooue very hardy, and sound able men. Nowe that yoᵘ lo may knowe, we are not the veriest beggers in the worlde, our Cowe-keeper here of Iames citty on Sundayes goes acowterd all in freshe flaming silkes and a wife of one that in England had professed the black arte not of a scholler but of a collier of Croydon, weares her rough beuer hatt wth a faire perle hattband, and a silken suite therto correspondent. But to leaue the Populace, and to come higher, the Gouernor here, who at his first coming, besides a great deale of worth in his person, brought onely his sworde wth him, was at his late being in London, together wth his lady, out of his meer gettings here, able to disburse very near three thousand pounde to furnishe himselfe for his voiage. And once wthin seuen yeares, I am persuaded (absit invidia verbo) that the Gouernor...
1501:
222 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

place here may be as proffitable as the lord Deputies of Irland. All this notwithstanding, I may say of my selfe, that when I was the last yeare with your lordship at Middleborough, si mens non laeua fuisset, I might haue gone to the Hagh with you, and founde my selfe there nowe in far better company, which indeed is the soule of this life, and might haue bene deeply ingrafted into your lordship's seruice, which since I haue a thousand times affected in vaine. And therfore seing I haue missed that singular happines, I must for what remaines, depende upon Gods prouidence, who, my hope is, wilbe so merciful towards me, as once more before I dye, to vouchsafe me the sight of your countenance, wherein, I speak vnfainedly, I shall enioye as muche happines as in any other thing I can imagine in this worlde. At my first coming hither the solitary vncouthnes of this place, compared with those partes of Christendome or Turky where I had bene; and likewise my being sequestred from all occurrents and passages which are so rife there, did not a little vexe me. And yet in these fiue moneths of my continuance here, there haue come at one time or another eleuen saile of ships into this riuer, but fraighted more with ignorance, then with any other marchandize. At length being hardned to this custome of abstinence from curiosity, I am resolued wholly to minde my busines here, and nexte after my penne, to haue some good book alwayes in store, being in solitude the best and choicest company. Besides among these Christall riuers, & odoriferous woods I doe escape muche expense, envye, contempte, vanity, and vexation of minde. Yet Good my lorde, haue a little compassion upon me, and be pleased to sende me, what pampletts and relations of the Interim since I was with you, as your lordship shall thinke good, directing the same (if you please) in a boxe to Mr. Ralfe Yeardley Apothecary (brother to Sir George Yeardley our gouernour) dwelling at the signe of the Hartychoke in great Woodstreet, to be sente to me by the first, together with his brothers thinges. This pacquett I deliuered to one Marmaduke Rayner, an Englishman, who goes intertained as Pilott in this Flemishe man of warre. If he come to your lordship, as he hathe promised, he wilbe the fittest messenger. All possible happines I wishe to your lordship, and to my most honoured lady; and though remote in place, yet neare in affection, doe reste

Your lordship's euer most humbly at your commaunde

Io: Pory

Iames citty in Virginia Sept. 30. 1619.

LXXXIII. GABRIEL BARBOR. A Letter to Sir EDWIN SANDYS

OCTOBER 2, 1619

Ferrar Papers Document in Magdalene College, Cambridge University. Autograph Letter, Signed List of Records No. 134

Sᵗ I vnderstand by yoᵘ tres, yoᵘ carefull plotting for Virginia; mʳ ffarrar shall rec: & yoᵘ also, his 100ᶫ, & yoᵘ 300ᶫ at yoᵘ time appointed. & by the begininge of ffebruarye next (if God pmitt) yoᵘ shall not fayle to rec: 2500ᶫ wᵗhout any greate hindrance of the coffionn stock, I suppose I shall pay itt sooner because I would haue yoᵘ haue the substance to incorage yoᵘ to continew yoᵘ rasaluéon herein; & if yoᵘ piect require 1000ᶫ more, I humblye desire yoᵘ to take my pmise therfor of wᵗ (if God will) yoᵘ shall not fayle of in March next: my bussinesses doth psper exceedinglye in these westerne partᵗ, where (I thinke) twill houlde till Christide; I pceaue smale Townes & greate markettᵗ, doth exceed the best Citties, & might deserue a new surveay through England & yett not retourne twice to any, when I shall heare the Courtᵗ resoluéon I shalbe right glad to be obedient & will euᵣ be to yoᵘ & yoᵘ a moste faithfull frend & Sᵉuant

Exeter 2 Oct: 1619.

GABR. BARBOR

[Indorsed by Sir Edwin Sandys:] Mʳ Gabr: Barbor to Sʳ Edw: Sandis Northb: in Kent

[Addressed:] To my Honᵈ friend Sʳ Edwin Sandis Knight at Northborn in Kent dd Hast.

LXXXIV. SIR EDWIN SANDYS. A Letter To JOHN FERRAR

OCTOBER 4, 1619

Ferrar Papers Document in Magdalene College, Cambridge University. Autograph Letter, Signed List of Records No. 135

Sᵗ I am put in good hope that yᵒᵘ wilbe here this week: wᵗ hope I trust yᵒᵘ will not suffer to faile me: & beleeve it there can be no man more welcom to me. I send yᵒᵘ here my answer to Sʳ T. Wolstenholms motion,
1503:
224 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY to be entered in the Court booke. But reserve it to the last: for it wilbe scanned by the evill eye. The Court wch you keep, shall have no reading of anie former Court: reserve that till my self come. So in hast, with hartiest commendacions, I rest in expectance of you. Your most assured Edwin Sandys Northborn 4. October: 1619. [Indorsed by John Ferrar:] from Sr Ed. Sande dated 4 October 1619 to John Ferrar [Addressed by himself:] To my very worthy Friend Mr John Ferrar Deputy of the Company for Virginia.

LXXXYV. Sir Edwin Sandys. A Letter to JOHN FERRAR October 18, 1619 Ferrar Papers Document in Magdalene College, Cambridge List of Records No. 136

Sr: I accounted my self much beholden to you for your so kynd visitation of me at Northborn. Your courteous acceptance of so ordinarie entertainment, (for you were my frend & familiar) dooth double your deserts. And you have trebled them by the iournie you have made for me to Sion. For all wch I return you threefold thankes & affection: wch shalbe redie to expresse it self really on your service, upon all fit occasions. I pray you not to faile to keep your Court on wendsday. You may please (if you see the Companie fit & in tune) to acquaint them that I am not idle in their busines, wch at the Court my self will make knowne unto them. If you fynd anie crosse proceedings, make a motion to have them referred to the quarter Court approaching. Let them knowe there are no generall letters to the Company come to my hands. Those to the Counseil I have a good while since caused to be presented to them: but they contein no matters of speedie consultation. That wch dooth concern the Companie, shalbe brought to them in fittyme. If wrong be offered, you may moove those of the Counceil wch are not factious, to goe from the Court, & your self goe with them, rather then the publick good or Justice should be oppressed by faction. But I hope there wilbe no such proceeding.
1504:
OCTOBER 18, 1619

225

I send you here two letters from Mr. Barbor for your comfort. But keep the contents very secret to yourself. There you find my care in 100 li to be paid to you. The 300 li for me (being of his own monie) is to supplie for a few weeks till my owne receipts come in. For I will make bold (seeing it will be this day fortnight when I set out from here) to put into your hands my payment of 500 li to the East India Companie at their day, the 29th of this instant. And for the other 200 li will take the best order that in absence I can. For I am exceeding loath to fail of one hour of my due time: which I know will be marked. Therefore make also this addition to your kindness towards me: I mean your care of this payment. If the 2 you write of will go in person to Virginia, for my part I shall be ready to further it: providing fit conditions for our friend who is there. But hereof more fully at the meeting. Now in haste I must end. All here heartily salute you. God's protection be with you. So prayeth

Your most assured friend

Edwin Sandys.

Northborn St. Luke: 1619

Remember my desire to Sr. W. C.

[Addressed:] To my very worthy Friend Mr. John Farrar Deputy to the Company of Virginia

LXXXVI. Counsell in Virginia.

“THE PUTTING OUT OF THE TENANTC THAT CAME OUER IN THE B. N. wᵗʰ OTHER ORDERS OF THE COUNCELL”

November 11, 1619

Ferrar Papers Document in Magdalene College, Cambridge University List of Records No. 138

James Citty Nouembᵉʳ 11 1619: By the gouernor & Counsell: Aboard the Bona Nova

As Concerninge the Company of a hundred new men sent hither in the barque Bona Nova to become Tennantᶜ ypon the Companies land and the Col- onells of Englishledge land fifty vnder the Comand of Captaine Weldinge and thother fifty to be Comanded by Lieutennant Whiteaker because ther provision of victualles beinge but 544 bushelle of English meale at yᵉ moderatte allowance of two poundᶜ of meale a day to a man would not last them above 5 Monthes and 14 dayes, and for asmuch as wee find by experience, that where abundaunce of new men are planted in one body they doe often overthrowe themselues either by Contagion of sicknes or by the mother Cause thereof, ill example of Idlenes, moreouer because diuers of those new men Cominge heither in tyme of winter might miscarry by lyinge in the woodᶜ before such time as Conveniente howses Could be erected for the harbouringe of them all, and lastly seeinge that most of these new men beinge put forth into the service of old planters, might not onely be p'sently howsed and prouided of necesaries but be trayned vp also in all the vsuall workes of the Country, and be well Seasoned for the publique service against another yeare.

It was thought expedient by the gouernor and Counsell to aduise the said two gentlemen to rent out the greatest part of ther people to some honest and sufficent men of the Colonie tell Cristmas Come twelue month for iij barrellᶜ of Indian Corne and 55ᵗʰ waight of tobacco a man wᵉʰ might abundantlie serve them for victuallᶜ and Apparrell for the yeare next ensuinge the expiraéon of ther time when as they should returne to the publique busines and be able to instructe other new Commers as they themselues had bine instructed;
1506:
NOVEMBER 11, 1619

If any of them should Chaunce to dye in the meane time the renters are to pay proportionably for their life time yf any doe fall sicke the renters are to stand to the hazard and at the terme of their service a steward is to be appointed to receiue their Annuity: Lieftenant Bartlett is to take to ferme till Cristmas Come twelue month eleuen of the Companyes men the remayner of fifteene that Came with Capt Lawne in the Marygold to Apparell and arme them and at the end of that terme to alowe 55' weight of tobacco and three barrelle of Corne to each man: Question beinge made of the danger of his seate beinge far from any other Englishe Plantation in the bottom of the bay Warrestogack he said he was Confident to make the place good against the Indians beinge a necke land and defended by his howse especially seeinge Lieftennant Basse and Ensigne Washer are to ioyne with him who together with his Companies will make up a party of thirtye men: He is to haue lent him the Crope newe reaped of the ground beinge 34 barrelle of eares and to repaye it the next Crop. It is thought most Convenient to seat Captaine Weldinge with his remaynder at Harrowatox in Consortship with Captaine Mathewes, both for his ease in buildinge there beinge two howses allready builte to his hand and for his securitye against Indians till he haue better strenthe and meanes to seatt. vpon the Colledge land for which purpose he went to the same place with Captaine Mathewes on Tewesday Night Nouemb 15: 1619: Lieftenant Whitakers Nouember 16 went with his remainder to seat himselfe vpon the Companies land some fower milles from James Citty westward toward the mouthe of the Chickahominie river: The Inhabitants of Kequohtan the bounde of the Comon Lande notwithstandinge are permitted to Continew vpon the seates wher they now are till they haue out of the same seates made them selues sufficient recompense for buildinge the howses and Clearinge the sand grounde. and are to Choose their divident alonge the banke of the great riuer betweene Kequohtan and Newportes Newes:
1507:
228 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

At the same Consultation November 11th the governor demanded the opinion of the Counsell concerning a piece revealed unto him by Neumettanan an Indian commonly called by the name of Englishe Jacke with the feathers at Charles hundredth the 25th of October: as from the part of Opachancamo who by the mouth of the same Indian required from the governor some 8 or ten Englishe with their armes to assiste him in battell against a people dwelling about a day's journey beyond the falls called Massituppamohtnock to be revenged of him for murdering certaine women of his contrary to the law of Nations, offering to furnish our people with Indian shoes to march and to carry their armor for them till they should have occasion to use it as likewise to share all the booty of male and female children: of corne and other things and to divide the conquered land into two equal parts between us and them. This piece those of the Councell embraced because they found the warre to be lawfull and well grounded the aid required to be very small and not of consequence enough for Opachancano to put any trecherous disaster upon, this the only way to oblige Opachancano who ever since St. George Yeardley's coming in hath stood aloof upon terms of doubt and jealousy and would not be drawn to any treaty at all notwithstanding all the art and endeavor the governor could use, the children taken in their war might in time serve as well for private uses of particular persons as to furnish the intended College this being a fair opportunity for the advancement of this blessed work seeing those Indians are in no sort willing to sell or by fair means to part with their children, lastly this course at least for the present might win amity and confidence from Jtoyatin the great King from Opachancano his brother and likewise from their subjects of these three rivers of Ronoake Powhatan and Pamunky.

By the Governor and Counsell at James Citty November 12, 1619:

Whereas according to a law enacted in the general Assembly four Tasters were to be chosen for setting down the prices of tobacco: It is thought fit by the governor and Counsell that these four viz. Ensign William Spencer: John Boys gent. John Jefferson gent. and John Tooke Mr. mate of the George should be appointed for that purpose, who for discharge of the same duty took this Oath following:

The humble peticion of many of ye first personall Adventurers, & Planters, willing & ready to prepare themselues, with Familyes thither agayne, The names hereupon due consideracion following.

[MARGINAL NOTE: Names of the Petitioners]

We, who preferr this Right Honorable Peticion in the behalfe of themselues, and ye rest of this Honorable Court: We doubt nothing, but you allowe itt, an approued truithe, that Great Actions are carryed with best successe by such Comanders, who haue personall Aucthoritye & greatness answerable to ye Action; Sithence itt is nott easye to swaye a vulgar and servile Nature, by vulgar & servile Spiritts; and surely in the raising of soe happye a State, as is hoped in ye Plantacion of Virginia, all cannot be select, but some such whom only Reuerence of ye Comanders Eminence, or Nobillitye (wherunto by Nature euerye man is subordinate and ready to yeild a willing submission without contempt, or repyning) may easely be perswaded under those dutyes of Obedience: which Aucthoritye conferred vpon a meane man, and of one no better, then selected out of their owne Ranke, shall neuer be able to compell: We vrge not this as willing to derogate from ye Gouernor who nowe holds ye Place, and hath succeeded the thrice Noble deceased Lo: Lawarr, whose Memorye, for this buissness be euar happye: vnto whom we suppose, if another, Noble like himselfe might haue risen vp, this buissness would haue found much willinger forwardness, and a great many olde Adventurers & Planters, both heare in England, would haue returned, together with manye new of Good Worth sett onwards: and many of ye Cheife there, who are even nowe readye to reuolt & looke home, would settle themselues with firmer Alacritye.
1511:
232 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

If then it may be supposed an Advancement to the Colony, to have both such who have suffered many years in the Early days of the business under his Loᵈ the Loᵈ Lawarr to return, and many voluntary forces to address them thither, as also to stay, and fix such of the better sort as be ready to come away, and all for want of some Eminent Commander: We humbly beseech this Honᵇˡᵉ Court to take into consideration this our only Request (who otherwise finding themselves much disparaged and wronged are resolved to abandon, and quit the Country, & Action for ever) that some, either Noble, or little less in Honor, or Dower may be maturely advised upon, to maintain & hold up the dignity of so Great and good a cause. And herein this Honᵇˡᵉ Court shall encourage many new, & ancient voluntary Adventurers, both of Good place, and Quality to set forward with expedition, both with great supplies of men, and other provisions.

His exception It was done delivered (as I

1512:
1620 (?) 233 heard) with more bitterness then it is penned yet by the very penning of it it seemes he did intimate some bitterness as though intimating some wrong done to the Companie by that order, nay (wherein I require more charitie) it was said that it was done to some ill end. I will first giue you full satisfaction in the thing it self and though I had thought I had then I will entreate you to giue me leaue to say something of the manner of his proceeding it is the first tyme that euer in my life I was driuen to a publicke Apologie, neither doe I know the cause but my comfort is I could not doe it before a more noble & Judicious & indifferent Auditorie blame me not that I be very sensible neither doe I thinke was euer any man of how meane condition so euer traduced vppon so slight an occasion. I will depose that I drew it vp with as much integritie and as neare set to the meaninge and determination of the Counsell as to my best remembrance I could possiblie doe, and though I am sure you will not thinke it a matter worthie blame either in my selfe or any other that shall doe you seruice in this kind, if being commanded to reduce it into writinge after conference of I thinke I may well say 2 houres at the least to set answere & determination of the Counsell consistinge of diuerse particulars I should in some one of them mistake in a word or two, & which vppon the least intimation were soone to be amended yet in this particular for you doe not therefore I am sure vse to desire any of our societie to take paines in any of your busines to thend that you may ferritt out some error whereby you may tax their proceeding Yet this exception which is now taken I must either iustifie to be vniust or I must betray offer wronge to myne owne knowledge, & therefore for this particular I say & affirme it to be the as I fully then conceaued & as still I doe remember no other then what was then agreed vppon [2] You may please to remember that vpon the 15th of Marche (for the order leadeth me directly to the remembrance of the tyme) there was a meet the Counsell was assembled by Sr. E. S. at Mr Ferrars house, where he proposed a letter drawne by (as I take it) by himselfe to be sent into Virginia & signed by 2 or 3 of the Counsell his priuate ffriends, this letter he pre read to the Counsell then jint to be by them allowed & signd.

Cert[ainly] I heuld it not fit to tell you th[is letter] after the dispatche of some businesses Capt Argoll preferrd to petition [to] th’ effect mentioned in the order, and after serious debate & consideration of the parts of it we grew wth one consent as I take it to the conclusions sett downe. It was desired that Mr. Treasurer those conclusions might be reduced into writing both to give Capt: Argoll satisfaction & to iustifie the equitie of our proceeding wth him. But much tyme being then spent & [the Court attending on our coming forth] it could not be then done sedente Curia, the Secretary was appointed to attend Mr. Threasurer for order to drawe it he sent him to me, who tho I was vnwilling to meddle wth it, yet at hauing neuer refused (how vnsufficient soeu[er]) to performe my best seruice in any thing layd vpon me & for that as I conceaued it tend[ed] much to aduance the reputation of our Just proceeding I did not refuse, I drew it up and I will depose wth as much integritie to as neare to the true meaning of the Counsell as I could possiblie, but I know am not so vayne as to think that in so many particulars I might not mistake, what did I before I would send it to the Secretary to be engroced I sent it to diuerse persons & to most of the gentlemen then present & first of all to Sr E. S. him selfe by [1] told prayed Capt Argoll [who attended as he sayes twice withal but if he were at home yet not to be spoken] intreating them that if they perceaued I had in any thing mistaken they would alter it: if it were acc[ording] to their meaning that they would sett their hands to it: Many of them Then The greater number then present agreeing it to be the er acc[ording] to their meaning I sent it to the Secretary from that day [this is above a quarter of a year ago] since which tyme I new heard any exceptions only one gentleman or two & that long after the drawing [of it] vp said they did not remember this particular now excepted (that he might choose any 2 of the Counsell to examine his witnesses if &c) only one gent said so much to me to whom I answered I remembered it very well. So as I hope you are now satisfied would aske of any man here present what he could doe more or wth lesse I professe it is want of iudgment in me if I haue not gone wth as euen a foote as is possible in this business. Now for this particular that it was the order of the Companie I profess I doe well remember so I doubt not but many more doe, & [even] those that

240 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

In two Shippes out of Ireland there are going one hundred Kine of English breed. There are now providing severall Shippes to transport the Governour, Treasurer, and Marshall of Virginia, with their Companies, together with other private Plantations, to the number of 400 persons.

100 Kine  
400 Persons  
1000

There are sent, and in sending, for publicke uses, five hundred persons, for the increase of the number of the Companies, Tenants, and for generall benefit.

500 Persons

Whereof besides the new Governour, there are six principal sent and chosen. To Master George Thorpe Esquire, as Deputie for the College land, 10 belong Tenants. To Captaine Thomas Nuce, as Deputie for the Companies, 50 belong Tenants. To the place of Secretarie of State, 20 Tenants. To Doctor Bohun, as Physitian to the Colony, with whom are also sent divers Apothecaries and Surgeons, 20 belong Tenants. To Master George Sandys Esquire, as Treasurer of Virginia, 50 Tenants. Men skillfull for setting up Staple Commodities.

There are three principall men sent again for Masters of the Iron works which are in some good forwardnesse, and a proofe is sent of Iron there made. Three sufficient men for perfecting the Salt-works: One a French man from Rochell which works are likewise there begun. Foure Dutch-men from Hambrough, to erect Sawing-Mills, and all provisions necessary thereunto. Eight French Vignerons, procured from Languedock, who are very skillfull also in breeding of Silke-wormes, and making Silke. Of this Seede there is good store gone, both French, Italian and Spanish: together with Instructions for providing Commodious housing, and orderly planting of Mulbery-Trees. There are also some Englishmen sent that have been trayned up therein.
