XCIV. John Rolfe. A Letter to Sir Edwin Sandys January 1619/20

Ferrar Papers. Document in Magdalene College, Cambridge. Autograph Letter, Signed, with Seals List of Records No. 154

Honored Sr

Studieng wth my self what service I might doe yo", as a token of my gratefull rememberance for yo" many favours and constant love shewed me, aswell in my absence as when I was present wt yo" I could not at this tyme devise a better, then to giue yo” notice of some pticulers both of of Pisent estate, and what happened since the departure of the Diana. And though I am well assured, yo” wilbe satisfied herein more fully by of Governo', yet I desire yo" kind acceptance of this my poore indeavo'.

Presently after the Diana hadd her dispatch St George Yeardley (according to a Commission directed vnto him and to the Councell of State,) caused Burgesses to be chosen in all place who mett at James City, where all matters therein conteyned were debated by severall Committees and approved: and lykewise such other lawes enacted, as were held expedient & requisite for the wellfare and peaceable government of this Comon-weale. Captaine Martines Burgesses for his Plantation were not admytted to this Assembly, the reasons I am assured yo” shall receive from o' Governo’, who sendeth home a report of all those proceedings.
1521:
242 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

These principall men being at James Citie, Capt. William Epps (who commandeth Smythes Hundred Company) was arraigned (as neere as might be) according to the laudable Lawes of England, for killing one Captaine Edward Roecroft als Stallenge. He came hither from the North Colony in a shipp of Sr. Ferdinando Gorges (as he sayd) for some necessaries which he wanted; and to coast along the shoare to fynd and discover what Harbors and rivers he could: but through neglect of the Master of the shipp and others she was forced aground in a storme neere Newports Newes, and there sprang so greate a leake, that he could not carry her back againe. This mischance happened through uncivill and unmanly words urged by Stallenge (there being no precedent malice) with which Captaine Epps being much moved did strike him on the heade with a sword in the scabbard with such an unfortunate blowe, that within 2. daies he died. The Jury (whereof Capt. Lawne was foreman a discreete and understanding man) hearing the Evidence, found him guilty of Manslaughter by Chaunce meddley. The Governor finding him (though young) yet a proper civill gent, and of good hopes, not long after restored him to his Command.

Captaine Henry Spelman being accused by Robte Poole (one of the interpreters of the Indian language) of many crimes which might be prejudiciall to the State in generall, and to every mans safety in particular, received Censure at this generall Assembly. But the Governor hoping he might redeeme his fault being proceeding much of Childishe ignorance, pardoned the punishment [1] upon hope of amendment. In triall whereof he was employed as interpreter to Patawamack to trade for Corne.

Captaine Ward in his shipp went to Monahigon in the No: Colony in May, and returned the latter end of July, with fishe which he caught there. He brought but a smale quantitie, by reason he hadd but little salte. There were some Plymouth shipps where he harbored, who made greate store of fishe, which is farr larger then New-land-fishe.

The George was sent by the Cape Marchant (with the Governor's consent) to New-found-land to trade and buy fishe for the better relief of the Colony and to make triall of that passage. One other reason (as I take it) was, for that the Magazin was well stoored with goods, it was somewhat doubtfull, whether a shipp would be sent to carry home the cropp so sone as the George might upon her returne back. She departed hence about the 9 of July, and arrived here againe about the 10: of September. She
1522:
JANUARY, 1619/20

243

made her passage to Newfound-land in less then 3. weekes, and was at the banck amongst the french fishermen in 14. daies. She came back hither againe in 3. weekes, with bare wyndes, and brought so much fishe as will make a saving voyadge, which, beside the greate releif, giveth much content to the wholl Colony. The Sturgeon shipp and the Triall departed hence together about the fiue of July. Mr. Pountys hath taken greate paines in fishing, and toward Michellmas (the weather being somewhat temperate) made some good sturgeon. He hopeth by the spring to be better fitted, with Cellars and houses, and to do some good therein. The Cattle in the Triall came exceeding well, and gaue the Colony much ioy and greate incouragement. Both they horses and Mares wilbe very vendible here a long tyme, the Colony increasing with people as of late. About the latter end of August, a Dutch man of Warr of the burden of a 160 tunes arriued at Point-Comfort, the Comander's name Capt. Jope, his Pilott for the West Indies one Mr. Marmaduke an Englishman. They mett with the Treasurer in the West Indyes, and determyned to hold consort shipp hetherward, but in their passage lost one the other. He brought not any thing but 20. and odd Negroes, which the Governor and Cape Marchant bought for victuall (whereof he was in greate need as he intended) at the best and easyest rate they could. He hadd a lardge and ample Commission from his Excellency to range and to take purchase in the West Indyes. Three or 4. daies after the Treasurer arriued. At his arriuall he sent word presently to the Governor to know his pleasure, who wrote to him, and did request myselfe Leiftenante Peace and Mr. Ewens to goe downe to him, to desyre [23] him to come vp to James Cytie. But before we gott downe he hadd sett saile and was gone out of the Bay. The occasion hereof happened by the vnfrendly dealing of the Inhabitants of Keqnoughton, for he was in greate want of victualls, wherewith they would not releive him nor his Company vpon any termes. He reported (whilst he staied at Keqnoughton) that if wee gott not some Ordnance planted at Point Comfort, the Colony would be quyte vndone and that ere long: for that vndoubtedly...
1523:
244 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

That the Spanyard would be here the next spring which he gathered (as was said) from some Spanyard in the West Indyes. This being spread abroade doth much disharten the people in generall. For wee haue no place of strength to retreate vnto, no shipping of certainty (which would be to vs as the wooden walles of England) no sound and experienced souldyers to vndertake, no Engineers and artmen to erect worke, few Ordenance, not a serviceable carriadge to mount them on; not Amunytion of powlder, shott and leade, to fight and 2. wholl dayes, no not one gunner belonging to the Plantation, so the King's soveraignes dignity, your honors, our poore reputations, lives and labor thus long spent lieth too open to a suddayne, and to an inevitable hazard, if a forroigne enemy oppose against vs. Of this I cannot better doe, to giue you full satisfaction, then to referr you to the iudgement and opynion of Capt Argall who hath often spoken and herof during his governm', and knoweth (none better) these defects.

About the begynnyng of September Japazous (the King of Patawamack's brother) came to James City to the Governor. Amongst other frivolous messages he requested, that 2. shipps might be speedyly sent to Patawamack where they should trade for greate stoore of corne. Herevpon (according to his desyre) the Governor sent an Englishman with him by land, and in the begynning of October, Capt Warde's ship and Somer-Island frigate departed James City hether-ward. Robte Poole being wholly ymployed by the Governor of messages to the King, persuaded Sir George, that if he would send Pledges he would, he but Contagious. would come to visite him. Our Corne and Tobacco being in greate abundance in our grounds (for a more plentyfull yere then this, it hath not pleased God to send vs since the beginning of this Plantation, yet very contagious for syeknes, whereof many both old and new men died) the Governor sent two men vnto him, who were returned with frivolous aunsweres, saying he never hadd any intent to come vnto him. The Governor being iealous of them (the rather because wee hadd many straggling Plantations, much weakened by the greate mortality, Poole lykewise proving very dishonest) requested Captaine William Powell and myself (for Opachankano professeth much love to me, and giueth much credite to my worde) to goe in a shallopp unto Pomonkey ryver: which wee did. Going vp that

[MARGINAL NOTE: Marginal notes by John Ferrar.]
1524: JANUARY, 1619/20 245 ryver within 5. myles of his house wee sent Capt Spelman and Tho: Hobson unto him with the Governor's message. The shipp and frigate (being not farr out of their way to Patawamack) went in the night about 12. myles into the river, and wee hasting upp with our shallopp, the messengers were with Opaihankano, before or assoone as any newes came to him eyther of the shipps or our arrivall, which much daunted them and putt them in greate feare. Their intertaynement at the first was harshe, (Poole being even turned heathen) but after their message was delyuered, it was kindly taken, they sent away lovingly, and Poole accused and Condemned by them, as an instrument that sought all the meanes he could to breake our league. They seemed also to be very weary of him. Opachankano much wondered I would not goe to him, but (as I wished the messengers) they said I was syck of an ague, wherewith they were satisfied. Wee hadd no order to bring Poole away, nor to make any shew of discontent to him, for feare he should perswade them to some myscheif in our corne feilds, hoping to gett him away by fayre meanes. So wee returned in greate love and amyty to the greate content of the Colony, which before liued in dayly hazard, all messages being vntruly delyuered by Poole on both sides. The Chikahomynies come not at us, but wee receyue no domage by them. The Governor hath bounded the lymytts of the 4. Corporations the Companies, the Governor, the Vniversity and Glebe lands according to the Commission. [38] All the Ancient Planters being sett free haue chosen places for their dividende according to the Commission. Which giueth all greate content, for now knowing their owne lands, they strive and are prepared to build houses and to cleere their grounds ready to plant, which giveth the * * * More hope then greate incouragement, and the greatest hope to make the Colony florrish that ever yet happened to them. Upon the 4. of November the Bona Nova arriued at James City. All the passengers came lusty and in good health. They came by the west Indyes, which passage at that season doth much refreshe the people.
1525:
246 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

The proportion of Victualle brought for those 100. men fell so short, that Captaine Welden and Mr. Whitaker were forced (notwithstanding our plenty) to putt out 50. or thereabouts for a yere, by the Governor and Councell's advise. For whom they are to receive the next yere, 3. barrells of corne and 55 lb of tobacco for a man; with their sicknes considered (for seldom any escapeth little or much) is more than they of themselves could ever gett. By this meanes the next yere, they will be instructed to proceed in their own busynes and be well instructed to teache new-comers. With the remaynder (being about 25. a piece, the one is seated with one Capt. Mathewes 3. myles beyond Henrico for his own securytie, and to his greate content. And Mr. Whithakers within 4. myles of James City on the Companies land.

Upon Saterday the 20 of November at night Mr. Ormerod died at James City, after a long and tedious sicknes, the chief occasion the flux, which of late hath much raigned amongst us. His death is generally much lamented, and the Colony receyving hereby a greate loss, being a man of so good life, learning & carriage as his fellow here he left not behind him.

One Mr. Darmer a gent sent out by the Plymouth Company arrived here about the end of September in a smale bottome of 7. or 8. tunnes, he hadd upon his returne coasted from Monahigon to our Plantation, and found an Inland sea to gaine out of the North of us, the depth whereof he could not search for want of meanes, Virginia went further to Discover and wynter coming on. He is fitting his smale vessell, and purposeth this Inland sea this spring to make a new tryall.

Capt. Lawne at his arrivall seated himself in Wareskoyack Bay with his Company, but by his owne sicknes and his peoples (wherein there was no one the improvidency) he quytted his Plantation, went up to Charles City, and about November died. So his project is likely (unless better followed and well seconded) to come to nothing.

Smythes Hundred people are seated at Dauncing Point, the most convenyent place within their lymitts. There hath bene much sicknes amongst them: so that this yere no matter of gaine or of greate industry can be expected from them.
1526:
JANUARY, 1619/20

Martynes Hundred men seated at Argall Towne with good & convenient houses have done best of all New-Comers. Many who were industrious having reaped good crops, but most not of equal spirit and industrious have less, yet exceeded other New-Comers. Many of these have also died by sickness, but not comparable to other places. About the latter beginning of December Capt. Ward with his ship and the frigate came from Patawamack. Japasons had dealt falsely with them, for they could get little trade, so that they brought not above 800 bushels, and the most part whereof they took by force from Japasons Country who deceived them, and a small quantity they traded for. But in conclusion being very peaceable with all the other Indians, at their departure they also made a firm peace again with Japazons. At this time also came Captain Woodiff in a small ship of Bristow, who brought his people very well, and made his passage in ten weeks. Thus far as part of my duty (ever ready at your service) have I briefly made known unto you, some particulars of our estate: and withal in conclusion cannot choose but reveal unto you the sorrow I conceive, to hear of the many accusations heaped upon Captain Argall, with whom my reputation hath been unjustly jointed [44] but I am persuaded he will answer well for himself. Here have also been divers depositions taken and sent home by the Diana, I will tax no man therein: but when it shall come to further trial, I assure you that you shall find many dishonest and faithless men to Captain Argall, who have received much kindness at his hands & to his face will contradict, and be ashamed of much, which in his absence they have intimated against him. Lastly, I speak on my own experience for these 11 years, I never amongst so few, have seen so many false-hearted, envious and malicious people (yea amongst some who march in the better rank) nor shall you ever hear of any the justest Governor here, who shall live free, from their scandal and shameless exclamations, if way be given to their report. And so desiring your kind acceptance hereof, being unwilling to conceal anything from yourself (who now, to mine and many others' comfort, standeth at the helm to guide us and bring us to the Port of best happiness, which of late we say principally by your goodness we now enjoy) either with you.
1527: 248 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY may be desyrous to vnderstand or wch may further yoᵘ for the advauncemᵗ of this Christian Plantation I take my leave, and will ever rest At yoᵘr service and commaund in all faithfull dutyes Jo: Rolfe. [Indorsed by Sir Edwin Sandys:] Mr John Rolfe from Virginia Jan: 1619. By the George. Narration of the Late p’cedings in Virginia. Cape Cod-fish larger then that of Nue-found-land The fishing voiage of the George. The Treasurors return: Extreme feare of the Spaniards: Want of all things. Ships sent to the K. of Patowamach. Voiage to Opuchankeno. Pooles villanie. { The 4. Burrough & publique land set out. h Joy and good successe of dividing yᵉ Lands. The Voiage of the Bona nova. Vide C. Weldons seate. Vide Death & praise of Mr Ormerod. Mr Damer of Plimmouths discoveries. Captain Ward’s Voiage for Corn. In favor of C. Argal. That people ill-conditioned To S Edwin Sandys. {Addressed by self:] To the Honored and my much respected frend Sr Edwyn Sandys Kt, Treasorer for the Virginia Company these. XCV. Sr George Yeardley. A Letter January 10, 1619/20 Smyth of Nibley Papers, Smyth, 14 Document in New York Public Library Autograph signed Right Worᵖ List of Records No. 155 Right Worᵖ Yoᵘ from Bristoll dated Septemb: 9, 1619. I have received from Captaine John Woodleef, whom accordinge to yoᵘr desire, I have planted in a very good and Conveniente place. Against wᶜʰ act of mine it may be, Captaine ffrancis West brother to yoᵘr late right honoᵇˡᵉ my Lo. la warre (accordinge to some false information from hence) will there in England take some
1528:
JANUARY 18, 1619/20

exception, as yf I had seated yoᵘ people vpon parte of that lande wᶜʰ he yᵉ last Somer designed for yᵉ right honoᵘʳᵇˡᵉ my Lo la warre nowe livinge. We yf he doe, yoᵘ may vpon mine affirmation boldly reply that Mr. West is misinformed, and that yᵗ lande I have made choyse of for yoᵘ, lyes above that wᶜʰ he had appointed for my lord, more towardᵉ West and Sherley hundred, and towardes Charles Citty, and also that he had not before his departure obtained any grante from me of that wᶜʰ he did lay out. ffor wyninge wᵗʰ yoᵘ presently in Adventure, though I give yoᵘ many thankes for yoᵘ favor, in admittinge me one of yoᵘ society, and would as gladly partake wᵗʰ yoᵘ as wᵗʰ any sowell in yᵉ Company, yet such nowe is partly my publique employmente, and partly my engagement to bringe out of England at my owne Chardge 25 men this yeare to furnish Smythe hundred as I must beseech yoᵘ to exeuse me, If I cannot at this tyme make vse of that speciall favor of yoᵘ, Hereafter it may be, when god shall give me ability and leysure, I shalbe more forward to accept yoᵘ Curtesy. In yᵉ meane while yoᵘ shall finde me as ready for yoᵘ sakes, to assist Captaine Woodleefe at all assayes, as yf mine adventure were allready in yoᵘ Cashe. So wishinge yoᵘ all and yoᵘ people here in Virginia yᵉ happines of a newe yeare, I rest

Yoᵘʳ verie ready to doe yoᵘ service

George YEARDLEY

James citty Jan. 10 1619

[Indorsed in the handwriting of Smyth:] Sr. geo: yardles l’r 10. Jan: 1619: of the Place assigued for our Berkely: and yᵗ it is not yᵉ lord de la-ware’s land: And yᵗ he refuseth to ioyne with vs.

XCVI. John Pory. A Letter to Sir Edwin Sandys

JANUARY 18, 1619/20

Ferrar Papers Document in Magdalene College, Cambridge. Autograph Letter, Signed List of Records No. 156

Most worthy knight,

After my sicknesses and miseries past, the Bona noua hath brought me in particular one singular and cordial comfort namely the newes of your being elected Treasurer: for nowe I am confident, that what
1529:
250 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

service soever I shall endeavour for the publique shall come to that hand with knowes how to value it, and will not only accept, but esteem it. The defect is (which makes me sigh) that my sufficiencies from hence (heu quantum est in rebus inane!) cannot in the thousand part answer yours every way so complete, out of England. And though I had it in my person, yet the place so newly inhabited wants many helps, wherewith those civiler parts do abound. Howbeit this year to come (for the last was full of infirmities in all kinds) so it please God to continue my health as it is, being never more perfect in any place wheresoever I have remained, I will rouse up my spirits to do all that may be possible. Neither shall the uncertainty of my being continued, or by some new governor thrust out of my place, any whit dismay me from performance of my duty for the Interim; for that is a stroke, though many times unjust and cruel, for which there is no sense. In this dispatch I have sent you enclosed in a letter of mine to the Counsel and Company, a copy of a warrant from the Governor and Counsel here, for establishing my fees, according as it was there ordered in court, before my coming away. Herein (as all of them can be my witnesses) I was not mine own carver at all; but they in [1] mine absence, and without my suggestion, did order mine allowance, as appeareth in the same copy. For the first whole year from the time my commission was delivered me, I received not a farthing, and since that, very little, being fain to trust the most of those I do service for. If the Company shall be pleased to confirm unto me that, which all men of reason here do think to be but reasonable, I shall esteem both my hazard and my pains well bestowed, although, do what I can, I fear me, that at my three years end I shall scarce make a saving voyage. In summa summarum, whatsoever they in their wisdom and bounty shall think fit to allot me I will rest contented.

Now in answer to your letter by the same ship. Your love I do most thankfully acknowledge; and I think Sir George Yeardley will not deny, but he hath still cause to affect me every day more and more. To that noble Earl I am deeply bound, who cannot but testify on my behalf, that when he employed me in his own particular service I performed it fully to his mind, and above his expectation, and will hope to do the like, if ever I shall have the honour to serve him again. As it hath been your endeavour to maintain his lo' good favour toward Sir George Yeardley,
1530: FANUARY 18, 1619/20 251 so (as you will perceiue by somewhat that comes in this dispatche) it hath bene my care to nourish Sir George his due respect and worthy seruice towards his loᵈ, and this also out of regard to the good of [24] Virginia. It would grieue me, that any error or disaster should haue any power to worke any contrary effecte. But you knowe that humanii est errare, and disasters what wisedome can preuent? If his loᵈ be offended in ought, it wilbe in respect of his more than ordinary affection towards Captain Argall, whose faultes Sir George was bounde by commission, and for the saluing of his owne reputation also, to discouer. Sir George Yeardley, I thinke, would not robb Captaine Argall of my lordes loue, for he hath in him to deserue muche; nor would he haue his loᵈ to haue spent so muche loue upon any man in vaine; but onely doth wishe that Captain Argall being riche, a Bachelour, and deuoid of chardge, would not so excessively intende his owne thrifte. As touching Sir George his intercepting of my letters, his loᵈ I knowe (so noble is he) will not be implacable. And on the other side, I knowe not howe he will interpret that wᶜʰ hath bene written concerning the Treasurer (wᶜʰ Argall called his ship, while she was here) or concerning Spelmans vnaduised using of his loᵈ name to Opochancano. Meane while in the dangers wherein the Colony stood, Sir George thought himselfe vnworthy of a remedy, vnlesse he had sett dewne the truth of the case. What tempestes that answere of his by the Diana, and those other letters then and since haue raised in your court, I doe almost fear to think of. Without his comandement I did nothing [2] and that wᶜʰ I did, he viewed and reuiewed still to a syllable. All wᶜʰ upon the sending away of this dispatch we throughly perused, and he constantly auowes and Justifies euery iota and title. Jacta est alea, and some body must run the hazard of it. But if we be blamed for doing part of our duty, then what should we haue bene, if we had done all? All that I can say is, that whatsoever errours of mine be represented back hither (for in the distemper I was in, I could not choose, but committe some) I shall be more willing to amende, than euer I was to committe, and shall honour them most, that read me my lesson most roundly. And whosoeuer do so, shall in my conceipte do far better, than those others (who they were, I knowe not) that by the Marigolde putt this gouernour for the time (whenas I serued him wᶜʰ the greatest fidelity and zeale that was possible) into so many violent needles Jelousies against me, which notwithstanding.
1531:
252 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

had not the force to batter downe my patience of prooff. That lawe of iustice and friendship so to doe right to one friend, as to beware of offring wrong to another, I haue as duely obserued, as I could any way deuise. And you shall well perceiue, howe I haue concurred with you to close up the breache, wch was in danger to haue growen wyder. So haue I ever since my coming hither performed the parte of a true friend, and that for the publique good, wherin I pray god, we may all haue Joye. For performing my requestes, wthowt answering my letters, I most humbly [34] thanke you. This far in answere of your kinde letter. I haue sente you in Sir George his boxe of letters directed both to your selfe, and to his brother, the copies of our two dispatches both by the Prosperous and the Flemish man of warre, to the ende, that if you haue occasion, you may make use of them. I haue sent you also inclosed wth this, the copie of my letter to you by the Fleming; and a copie also of my letter I write nowe to my lord of Warwick, to the end you should from my part, be ignorant of nothing wherby you may doe any good office between that most noble lord and Sir George Yeardley, and for none other purpose. This secret I would not putt into any hand but yours, nor into yours, but onely for that intent. I am to confident of your true worth, as I dare putt my life into your handes, and therfore this, wch I hold not much inferiour. By the Bona noua I purpose to sende you copies of suche graunts of lande, as we shall haue passed to the ende, that if you like not the forme, you may be pleased to reforme it. If you receiued Sir George his dispatehe by the Prosperous I would beseech you to viewe the general petition against Captaine Argall of those nine of James citty, contained in one sheet and to compare the original wth the copie sent you nowe in Sir George his boxe, and if you finde neuer so little difference between them though but a worde that you would vouchsafe to giue me notice by the first, for it may concerne me. You may best doe it by correcting the said copie by the original, and sending it back againe. More time I will not presume to rob you of, that haue so many better wayes to employe it. [85] Mine humble duty and seruice I beseech you to present to your noble and vertuous lady. And so wishing her ld°, your selfe, and your generous ofspring all happines, I reste Yours euer most humbly bounden to loue and serue you. Jo: Pory. James Citty Jan. 13th 1619.
1532: JANUARY 13, 1619/20 253 Postscript Whereas in my letter by the Fleming I wrote concerning Poole the Interpreter, that Sir George would make him sure for telling any more false tales to Opochaneano, if once he got him into his power; at Poole's coming lately home we were quite of another opinion. For bringing the King's picture as a messenger from Opochancanough, we counted him a publique, and as it were a neutral person, and so for not discontenting Opochancanough, with whom now we stand in terms of reconciliation, we thought it no ways convenient to call Poole to account. One favour yet I must humbly beseech of you, and that is, after this dispatch hath been perused in the court, you would be pleased to send it my lo: Carewe to read it over, and likewise if there be any thing with his lo: hath not seen in the last dispatch by the Fleming. At the sealing up of this I cannot find the copie of my letter to you by the Fleming, which, it may be, you shall find in one of the other pacquette. [Indorsed:] Mr John Pory: from Virginia 13 Jan: 1619. By ye SGeorge. Bene news + Sent ye order for his Fees. Apologie for his dealing between ye E. & SG. Y. What if they had done all their Duetie? Trust with a Secret. Will send copies of their grants of Land. (J Touching ye Complaints by ye Prospus vide. Poole a messenger from Opachankeno, [By Sr Edwin Sandys] To Sr Edwin Sandys. 1282—33——18
1533:
254 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

XCVII. John Pory. A Letter To Sir Edwin Sandys January 14, 1619/20

Ferrar Papers Document in Magdalene College, Cambridge List of Records No. 157

Honoured knight,

Untill the last moment of sending away, I had forgotten to write you a list of their names both Colony men & other passengers that came in the Bona nova, whereby it appeareth, there want three Colony men of the number of an hundred. Nor doth it appear whether the passages of all the rest that in the same note go under the name of Passengers be payd for, or freely given by the Company. Captain Welden saith, the Company gave him passage for two, Thomas Smyth and Edward Kerby gentlemen, which the Governour will not accept of as a warrant sufficient to save him harmeles, without certificat from the Company. These two, together with Adames that goes under the name of Mr Whitakers man, the Governour will not let passe for England; nor yet Mr Hansbies man in pledge of George Eden that by your order is to go for Smyths hundred, till such time as he receive other order from the Company, or untill there come three others in their roome.

[MARGINAL NOTE: To be found in Of Vignerons, of those that have skill in breeding silkewormes, and such as know how to handle and dresse flaxe for the managing of our silke about Cambray grasse.]

If the company will not have most of their ships continually to returne home empty, there would be good numbers sought out and sent. Because the boat stayes, I must abruptly take my leave. Dieu vous guarde de mal. Monsieur Vostre tres humble et tres affectioné serviteur

Jo: Pory.

James city Jan. 14. 1619.
1534: JANUARY 16, 1619/20 255 XCVIII. John Pory. A Letter to Sir Edwin Sandys January 16, 1619/20 Ferrar Papers Document in Magdalene College, Cambridge. Letter, Signed List of Records No. 158 Honorable Knight Once more give me leave to interrupt you in answering an objection which some may make against Sir George Yeardley for preferring to serve the Company in his place of his government, for his three years in case he be continued gratis. Against this some man may allege that he hath broke his proffer in taking this year a rent of Corn and tobacco, though not much, from Martins hundred people, whom Capt Argall had placed on the Governor's land. To this he answers, first that what he received from them did not arise out of the labors of those fifty of his guard, which the Company allowed him, by whose labor he hath not yet reaped a penny benefit, save only and merely in Corn, which he cannot convert into money, because he must reserve it for his next year's provision. Secondly he is at least 800 pounds sterling out of purse by reason of this chargeable employment and that if he should heal up his estate again out of the Governor's land, only to that suffice, and no farther, yet might he be said to serve them, gratis, having made but one of one. But still he professeth as in his former that he consecrateth that expense wholly to the service of the Colony, that he will not from henceforth raise a penny profit out of those men's labor that remain of his guard, or that shall be sent over for a farther addition, but apply it wholly to the building and maintaining a fort at Point Comfort: and lastly that he took that petty rent of Martins Hundred people, to make them acknowledge by the same act of theirs that Paspaheigh by express words in the great Commission did belong to the Governor and that they had been wrongfully seated by Capt Argall upon that land, with both he had instructions, and Sir George Yeardley Commission to lay out for the Governor's use.
1535:
256 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

Sr George adviseth not onely the Adventurers for Smythes hundred, but the generall Company also, to send hither husbandmen truely bred (whereof here is a greate scarcity, or none at all) both to manage the Plough, and breake our oxen and horses to that busines. Besides he wisheth the generall Company would send greate store of Vignerons, and Vine plants of a good race though growinge in England, albeit they woulde doe better to be had of ffrance and Spaine. Mr Nicholas Leate the Marchant hath vpon my knowledge or (I am sure) had a lardge vine of Corynth grapes at the house he formerly dwelt in the garden whereof Containinge the same vine is parted but by a wall from the garden of the house where he nowe dwelleth. It grewe when I sawe yt against the North wall of the same garden which supported it towarde the South sune. If you Could procure any slips of that howe gainfull might they prove with in seven or Eight yeares, heere beinge heat enough both to ripen and to dry them? There belonge so many severall skills to the plantinge and dressinge of a vineyard and to the makinge and preservinge of wines, whereof our nation is ignorant, as needes must wee have Vignerons frem from forraine partes: And vineyards beinge once planted where such infinite store of caske may be provided, wee might for want of other commodities lade all the ships that come, with as rich wines as ffrance or Spaine doth yeild. Sr George brought hither some plants which doe prosper passinge well, but his Vigneron being a fretfull olde man is dead. And because Canary wine is the most durable in all voyages and Climates of anie, and so Consequently the most salable and proffitable: yt would doe passinge well, yf wee could get store of plants from thence, * * * yt would one day acquite the Cost to procure plants of those wines * * * ly and Greece, which doe emulate the Nectar. Then this, Store of Vines all along Country is more apt for that purpose; for in time of yeare you Can places scarce walke three steps in any place vnmanured, where some vine or other will not be ready to entangle your foote. But of this subiect enough, Brauely Spoken whereof I have so lardgely dilated, not because I thirst after yt; for I thanke god, I drinke water here with as much (yf not more) pleasure and contente, as I dranke wine in those partes.
1536:
JANUARY 16, 1619/20

For the breeding also and attendance of silke-wormes, it would be most necessary to send hither men that have in other Countryes beene trayned up meerely to that profession. For there belongeth greate Curiosity to it. For the dressing, hatchelling, and making merchantable silke grasse, flaxe, and hempe, hither would be sent men of professed and practised skill—it may be some might be founde in England.

Of Silke Grass, Tobacco onely takes up as much labor and care, as all these (yea if you should adde some one Commodity more) Can employ or exercise. For in sowing, planting, weeding, worming, gathering, Curing, and making up, it Consumes ten monethes at least, if not eleven. Yet this benefit we may very truly say by it. The extreame Care, diligence, and labor spent about it, doth prepare our people for some more excellent subject. All those other Commodities can prosper in a wet yeare, when tobacco proves naught. Besides they are not in danger of frost, which sometimes overthrowes the greatest parte of the tobacco in the lande. And though this yeare (which was a most extraordinary good yeare both for Corne and Tobacco) I thinke there will goe home ten thousand waighte at least as good as ever Came out of the Indies; yet are we not to set our rest upon a Commodity as much importuned as little necessary. When I sate downe I thought to have wryt but ten lines at the most. But the true and unfained respect I beare to your worthy selfe, my love to the Country, and those flourishing hopes which not in remote, but in neare possibility I doe Conceive of it, doe make me forget that other respect I should Carry to the price of your time, which else would be far better employed. To my selfe I dare not presume to wish such a degree of happines, as I doe to you, which if I might have my desire, should be with the most, And in that minde, which I hope shall never change, I rest

Your most bounden to serve and honour you

James Citty Jan. 16: 1619.

One thinge more I am willed to adde for a Postscript; and that is a reason yet unalleadged why the greater parte of the Companies and Colledge men sent hither in the Bona Nova are put out to olde planters. It is because those that the Company hath appointed to governe them are men quite...
1537:
A good Consideration

258 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

unexpercienced in this Country, and therefore not fit to take so greate a chardg vpon them at ye first, as ye Comaundinge and ye directing and orderinge of fifty men a piece. The greater parte of wch by that time their yeares service to those old men is expired, wilbe men well seasoned and skillfull to labor themselves and those two gentlemen their Governo'rs by that tyme also wilbe more apt to take chardge over them all.

Two other packets I haue sent you from my selfe, the one by this bearer Mr. Ewens Mr. of the George, and the other inclosed in a letter to Mr. Ralph Yeardley, putt up in the lesser boxe of the twoe, wch Sir George Yeardley now sendeth you.

[Indorsed by Sir Edwin Sandys:] John Pory from Virginia 16. Jan: 1619, By * * * Reasons of Rent taken by Sr. G. Y. from Mart. Hun. The Paspaheys land. Store of True Housbandmen to be sent. Vignerons & Vines from Fr: and Spain. Mr. Letes Corinthian Vine. Vines from the Canaries best. Abundance of naturall Vines there. Men skilfull for Silkworms & Silk to be sent. Item for dressing flax & so ye Silkgrasse. The Extreme labor (of 10 Moneths) about Tobacco hath prepared them for better things. They send 10th of the best Tobacco that ever grew in Virginia. As good as ye Spanish. The men put out, because their Governors unexperienced. To Sr. Edwin Sandys.

XCIX. Sr Edwin Sandys. A Letter to Sir Robert Naunton

JANUARY 28, 1619/20

State Papers, Domestic, James I, Vol. 112, No. 26, Folio 49

Document in Public Record Office, London. Letter Signed and Sealed with Coat of Arms

List of Records No. 160

Right Honorable: Being vnable to give my personall attendance vpon the Ll*, I have presumed to addresse my Suite in theis few lines vnto yoᵘ Honor. The Citie of London have by Act of their Common Counsell, appointed one Hundred Children out of their superfluous multitude to be transported to Virginia; there to be bound apprentices for certaine yeares, and afterward wᵗʰ verie beneficiall conditions for the Children; and have granted more- over a levie of five hundred pound among them selfs for the apparrelling of those Children, and toward their charges of transportačon. Now it falleth out that among those Children, sundry being ill disposed, and fitter for any remote place then for this Citie, declare their vnwillingnes to goe to Virginia: of whom the Citie is especially desirous to be disburdened; and in Virginia vnder severe Masters they may be brought to goodnes. But this Citie wanting authoritie to deliver, and the Virginia Company to transport theis persons against their wills: the burden is layd vpon me, by humble suite vnto the Ll to procure higher authoritie for the warranting thereof. May it please yoᵘ Honor therefore, to vouchsafe vnto vs of the Company here, and to the whole Plantation in Virginia that noble favouᵘ, as to be a meanes vnto their Lᵈˢ out of their accustomed goodnes, and by their higher authority to discharge both the Citie and our Company of this difficultie, as their Lᵈˢ and yoᵘ Honors in yoᵘ wisedomes shall find most expedient For whose health and prosperity our Company will alwaies pray. And so I take humble leave: and rest yoᵘ Honors humbly at Comand

Edwin Sandys

London 28 January 1619

[Addressed:] To the Right Honorable Sr Robert Naunton Knight princi- pall Secretary to his Maᵗᵉ

Right Worshipful Sirs,

I am truly honored to address you, the esteemed members of the Cordwainers' Company, and to express my gratitude for the support and patronage you have extended to me. It is with great respect and admiration that I acknowledge the invaluable contributions you have made to the trade and the city.

Your dedication to the craft and the community is unparalleled, and it is my sincere hope that you will continue to thrive and prosper in all your endeavors. The legacy of excellence and integrity that you uphold is a testament to the rich history and tradition of the Cordwainers' Company.

I am deeply grateful for the opportunities you have provided, and I am committed to upholding the standards of excellence that you exemplify. It is my privilege to serve alongside such distinguished individuals, and I look forward to many more years of collaboration and success.

With the highest regard and respect,

[Your Name]

CII. Wittram Wetton. A Letter to Sir Edwin Sandys March 6, 1619/20

Ferrar Papers Document in Magdalene College, Cambridge. Autograph Letter, Signed, with Seal List of Records No. 166

Harrowhattocke the 6th of March. 1619.

Honorable Sr May it please you to vnderstand that vpon the 10 of August wee set sayle from Deale & havinge a faire & prosperous winde held our Course toward the Caribo Islande & vpon the 27th of Septemb: fell w Metallina & the 8th of Octob: ancored at Menis from whence wee depted the 11th of Octob: & after some stormy & tempestuous wether ariued at pointe Comfort vpon the 29th of Octob: & the 4th of Nouemb: followinge ancored before James Citty where we landed all our people in as good or better health then they were when they came abord a wonderfull & miraculous passage the like whereof hath not bene knowne since the first plantation of this Country wherein the lord plainly sheweth that he loueth the gates of Sion more then all the dwellinges of Jacob.
1545:
MARCH 6, 1619/20

Blessed be his glorious maiesty for this & all other his mercies, & may his love euer continue to this his poore Vine that the roote of it may fill the land & the hills may be couered with the shadow of it. And truly the experience of his former mercies (in preseruinge vs in that extreame hot Climate in a ship so exceedingly pestered) assureth me that he will doe this & much more for vs if our sins hinder him not. But honorable Sr. the great defecte of the provisions promised in England hath very much greiued me & almost dishartened my whole Company for whereas the tennants were promised 3. suites of apparell for euery man, full armes & a Competent provision of houshold stuffe, I finde here but 2 suites of apparell for a man (& one of them soe meane & vnseruiceable that it will not defend them from the iniury of the wether wch hath bene extreame Cold euer since our Cominge hether) but 30 muskets, 5. iron pots & 1. small kettle for 50. men. To omit the promises of kine & other thinges (wch I hope wilbe performed) our maine provision of victualls is so short that the Gouernor & Capemerchant seeinge my Inuoice protested I had not a Competent proportion for 50. men for aboue 4. monethes havinge only 32 hhde of meale & a small quantity of oyle & neither butter, Cheese, rice, oatmeale or any other English victualls. In regard whereof the Gouernor & Counsell thought it fitt to put out the one halfe of my Company for their victualls this yere & a proportion of Corne & Tobacco to victuall & apparell them the next yere wch I was Constrained to doe to my owne great greife & the no small discontent of my whole Company. All wch inconueniencies I perswaded them to beare with patience & Cherefullnes vntill I acquainted them with my restraint of plantinge Tobacco wch is a thinge so distastefull to them that they will with no patience indure to heare of it, bitterly Complayninge that they haue noe other meanes to furnish themselues with apparell for the insuinge yere but are likely as they say (and for ought I Cann see) to be starued if they be debarred of it. In regard of wch necessity & to make them beare their present wants with more alacrity & for that I am perswaded it is a thinge pleasinge to God that men imploied in so noble a busines should haue any Christian incouragement I am bold to intreat inlargement of my authority in that pointe & haue with the allowance & good likinge of the Gouernor giuen them leaue to plant some this yere but will restraine them to so smale a quantity as possibly I Cann by inioyninge them to sett so much Corne as they shalbe able to attend.
1546:
264 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

The land appointed for the Colledge is from Henrico to the falls of which I may say with David her lot is fallen to her in a faire ground shee hath a goodly heritage beinge as pleasant & fruitfull a soyle as any this land yeeldeth. But one of the best seats is already planted by Captaine Mathews for the use of Sr. Thomas Midleton & Alderman Johnson & another Challenged by Thomas Dows by a grant from Captaine Argoll one of them beinge now ready for the plough & the other most Convenient for pasture both of them nere the place of my plantation & most fittinge for my present use. The Governor whom I have founde a noble favorer & furtherer of this busines hath given them both warninge to departe & take ground elsewhere which they have hether to forborne to doe trustinge that the company will Confirme Captaine Argoll his grant which I hope you will forbeare to doe in regard these 2. seats are the most convenient & likely to prove the most beneficiall for the present use of the Colledge. There is small likelihood of any profit from my people this yere in regard the number of them is but small & some of them Continually imployed in fetchinge up our provisions & the rest of them I have imployed in buildinge Convenient housing for themselves & the use of supplies which I expect of which I found great want & they shall receive no small Comfort. For my owne part I will doe my uttermost endeavour to make their labors profitable howsoever I have hetherto received but small encouragement yet seeinge by former experience that God hath beene good to Israel & beinge undoubtedly persuaded that he will still continue to bee soe I have Comforted myselfe & am bold to encourage you to send such supplies as you intended which if you doe I pray you send such as have bene brought up to labor & those between 20. & 30. yeres of age for old men either live not or doe little service in this Country & above all let me intreat you to send them well provided both of victuals & apparell for I Cannot be supplied here (upon any termes) of such necessaries as my Company extremely wanteth although I have both spoken & sent & written to the Capemarchaunt. In regard whereof I have dealt with the bearer hereof Thomas Smith (being one of the 2. men which I brought over for my owne use) who intendeth to bringe a ship & men hether with all Convenient speed to bringe me such men & necessaries as I shall want for my owne private occasions & to supply the want of my Company humbly intreatinge that he may have a Commission to that purpose.

I hope you will not deny vnles some other order be taken to furnish the Company with things necessary. And thus not havinge further to inlarge, humbly Comittinge your worship & all your indevours to God's mercifull protection & direction I rest

Your's in all humility to Command

WILLIAM WELDON

Sr I was glad of yor letter & yor good nues of Virginia, but sori yor ship is not retorned god send her a hapi Coming & all ouer bisnes hapili to go on to gods glori & ouer good there is a gust Caues yt I Canot met at Gloster, as ye loue me Condem me not so do I intret my Cosin Barkli what so ever ye do agre on I will Consent vnto be Caues I am asured ye will do nothing vnfitting ye selves Yf I may know wher to met my cousin Barkli ye first nite I will not fayle & it may be goe a long with him to London Yf not with you yf ye go from ouer parts. but at London ther shall we haue tim suffisient to determen all I am now binding my men I haue at lest 20 promised me ye most part I am suer of. there is no dout of more then wee men at this to Cari. ti all of usefull trads so ye we may leaue those ye ar of lest imployment tel ye next going do as ye plese with William Throkmortun I will do nothing but as ye aduise me Yf I proue not ferm & faythful let me not be held worthi ye nam of a Cristion this hoping this may geve ye satisfactione I rest Yor in all asurance

MAY, 1620

CV. Copy of Opinion of Counsel upon the Patents of the Virginia Company

May, 1620

Manchester Papers, No. 271

Document in Public Record Office, London

List of Records No. 170

Upon Consideration of the patents & of the questions moved thereupon, I am of opinion as followeth.

1. That Sr Thomas Smithe is not so absolutely made Treasurer by the 2nd patent as that he is not removable by the laws & orders of the company; either upon his own Desire to surrender the place; or upon other cause which they shall conceive to be reasonable; for although it may seem a hard exposition of the words (or other several occasions) that their wills shall be taken as an occasion to remove him; without expressing any just cause in certain yet when they have removed him by a general consent; it is not now to be questioned (as I Conceive) whether they had lawful cause or no; but their doings are to be holden lawful & just: & that by the intention of the 2nd patent without any help of the third; But when a Law (by authority of the 3rd patent is made) at a general court by Consent of the whole Company that all officers shall cease at such a time & new to be chosen; that is binding, & makes this point without question as I take it.

2. That by the clause of the 3rd patent where the words are (we do give & grant to the said Treasurer & Company & their successors forever by these presents, that the said Treasurer & Company or the greater number of them so assembled (viz at the general quarter Court) shall & may have full power & authority to choose Councillors & officers & to make laws &c. That in this case the greater number of the Company without the Treasurer may make Laws &c: & that as well when there is no Treasurer at all, as when he is absent; for as I do conceive this great & general Quarter Court which is appointed by the 3rd patent only may be held without any Treasurer at all; and all things are to be dispatched there by the greater number of the company then assembled, & that by the express words of the patent; for although the
1550:
268 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

graunt be to the sayd treasurer & Company for the doinge of theis thinges at this Court, yett that is but for forme onely, because all grauntes must be made to them by there name of Corporation & yt is not requisite that the treasurer should be privie or haue any voice in the makinge of theis Lawes; But for the holdinge of the petty Courts apointed by the patent, (& to be summoned by the treasurer) the treasurer must be one by expresse wordes, but so it is not here; Neither hath the treasurer any negative voice in the makinge of theis Lawes, nor can hinder the doinge of any thinge wch the greater nomber of the Company at this generall Court will do; and therefore in reason his presence is not needfull, the rather seinge he is not appointed by the patent to be present, as he is at the other Courte.

3. I am of oppinion that the Company (without the treasurer) having power to make Lawes at the generall Court, haue also power to repeall & abrogate all or any former Lawes as yt seemes they haue done, for the Lawe of repeall is a Lawe as well as the former & eodem modo quo Constituitur Dissoluitur; And so the Lawes that were made for the degrees of establishing Lawes, & for election of officers by the balladinge boxe, though they were excellent & Comendable; yett being repealed by the same authority they were made, they are gone & determined.

4. Sr. Edwin Sandes cannott be Continued treasurer by the act of the company vpon his former election, for that is against the Lawe of the company that all officers shall cease at the quarter courte Day in Easter terme yearely; but the Company may then choose him anewe, as yt is likely they did.

5. I thinke that the Company here hath no power by the wordes of the 2 patent either to punishe or pardon offences comitted in Virginia especially in Capitall or criminall causes; 1 because they haue no power to proceed here against any such offence, as the gouernor there may do; & yf not to proceed against it then not to pardon yt; 2 although that graunt of the patent, be aswell to the treasurer & Company & there successors, as to the gouernor; yett the power is given to them accordinge to the natures & Limitts of there offices & places, respectiuely, that they shall & may within the precincts of Virginia or in the way by the seas thither &c: haue full power to Correct.
1551:
MAY 1, 1620 269 punish pardon govern & Rule &c: Nowe when a governor is chosen & sent thither he hath a kinde of Regall power to execute Lawes & to punishe offenders there and also to pardon them yf he see cause & that by the wordes of the patent; wch is more then the Company can do here; for any offence Committed here, where the offence requires the punishment of life or member; muche lesse for any offence done there (as I Conceyve) because they are not to execute any Lawes there but by their governor; And besides so muche may be gathered vpon the wordes of the 3 patent where the Company are authorised to remaund & send backe offenders to Virginia there to be punished and proceeded against accordinge to the Lawes there established for offences there comitted, and the reason is apparant because that by those lawes nor by any other they Cannott be proceeded against here for offences done there, nor pardoned here when they are proceeded against there; And so I thinke that for all matters wherein the governor may proceed there by lawes there established, & for matters proper to his Government, the Company here haue no power to Controll his acts: And the clause of the 3 patent. whereby the Company are authorised either to punishe misbehaviour or Contempts or to send the offenders to Virginia to be punished is to be taken severally & distributively reddendo singula singulis; that is for offences that are committed against the company here (& against wch they may proceed) they may punishe the offenders here; But for offences done in Virginia against the peculiar Lawes there established for that government, they must send the offenders thither to be punished or not at all; and being proceeded against there by those Lawes, they are not to be pardoned here; And this I take to be the playne meaninge of both the patents touching this point. 

[Indorsed:] Opinion vpon Virginia patent. 

CVI. Sir Edwin Sandys. A Letter to JOHN FERRAR May 1, 1620 Ferrar Papers Document in Magdalene College, Cambridge. Autograph Letter, Signed, with Seal List of Records No. 171 Good Mr. Ferrar: I have not heard from you since I saw you wch assures me you have been thoroughly wrought: & how could it be otherwise? But I heard (wch contented me) first by Mr. Bluet & My Cosen David Sandys, 1282-33 $19
1552: 270 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY who have been here these 3 dayes, & since by Captain Wilkins, who came this morning, that ye were very well. We expected this morning, that the Bonaventure would have been come about: now they expect hir this evening. And till then I am told that I may not stirr from hence, by reason of som writings which must have my hand unto them, for as for my owne letters, they are readie to an haire: having spent in a manner all my tyme here, in writing letters & Directions, to & for Virginia. For I have left neither person, nor thing unanswered: nor omitted anie thing to the best of my understanding, which might serve for advancement of the busines. So carefull have I been to be no example of negligence: which I knowe our people there would be too prone to imitate. This I knowe ye will hold for a iust cause, & no exeuse, of my abode here longer then I before had purposed. But would to God there were no other cause then that. Then should I be free from as much sorroe, care, & feare, as I ever endured for anie one thing in my life. For my wife by reason of a fever, which seazed on hir last thursday, hath had such an inflammation on the one side of hir neck, that it hath excoriated hir throte on the inside, which is most dangerous for hir life. And although I humbly thank God, we hope it beginneth now to hele: yet dooth it deprive hir (beeing with chyld) of all strengthning nourishment, & thereby is as dangerous to hir & hirs another way. Twice she hath been let blood, & one tyme purged: which also encreaseth hir weaknes. All which notwithstanding, such & so strong is hir affection, that she will by no meanes be persuaded to stay behynd me: so that on Thursday God permitting we set out, entending to take leysure, & make it three days woork. I have enlarged to ye these particulars, that ye may thoroughly free me from blame. Besides in verification of the Italian Proverb, Il mal non viene mai scompagnato; my Coachman going one evening to Sandwich, & falling into the hands of thiefs, was so grievously beaten & wounded that hetherto we have very small hope of his life: though he be dayly looked to by a good physitian & surgeon: which enforceth me to be bold with som of my neighbores to borroe one. Howsoever, if I be alive, looke for me on Saturday. Mean tyme, I pray ye keep Wendsday Coort: though for no other busines, yet to revive the three Committees set on foot before Easter.
1553:
MAY 7, 1620

271

The first, for examination of the Acts of the Generall Assembly in Virginia. The second, for the prizes unpaid, & monie unbrought in of the Great Standing Lottarie. The third, for all the Debts yet due by the Companie. On the same day I pray you also not to faile, to begin your Accounts of this yeare with the Auditors: (for so is the order:) for when you are finished, mine will hold them but one hower. I trust you have taken order with Mr. Barbor, to be here by this Day fortnight at farthest: that so all our Accounts may be made clere & perfect. I would be glad that my Lord of Southampton knew the necessitie of this my stay here, to stop such suggestions as my unfrends may make. So with hartiest commendation to you & all yours, I rest also Your assured Edwin Sandys Northborn 1. Maij: 1620.

May 7, 1620

Smyth of Nibley Papers, Smyth 3 (20), pp. 100-102 Document in New York Public Library List of Records No. 172

[100] This Indenture made the seventh day of May, 1620, in the xviijth yeare of the raigne of our soueraigne lord king James of England, France and Ireland and of Scotland the liijth Betwene Sr. Willm Throckmorton of Clowerwall in the County of Glouces knight and baronet of the one part And Willm Tracy
1554:
272 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

of Hayles in the said county Esq of the other part. Whereas the said Sr. William Throckmorton, Sr. George Yardley knight, Richard Berkley Esq, George Thorpe Esq, and John Smyth gent. did procure from the Treasurer and company of Adventurers and planters of the city of London for the first Colony in Virginia by the advise and consent of the Counsell of the same One Indenture of Covenants and grants sealed with their Comon seale bearing date the third day of February in the xvjth yeare of his maties said raigne of England and of Scotland the lij for their better enabling and incouragement for plantation in Virginia aforesaid And for divers other causes purposes and intents As in and by the same Indenture more at large it doth and may appeare. And whereas in pursute of the said Indenture of Covenants and of the intents and purposes aforesaid one ship was in September last past sent for the causes aforesaid from the port of Bristoll into Virginia at the sole charges of them the said Sr. William Richard Berkley George Thorpe & John Smyth with forty persons or thereabouts furnished at their charges with all things necessary and convenient for plantation, whose safe arryvall in Virginia is from thence certifyed by the governor and secretary of the said land of Virginia. Nowe this Indenture witnesseth that the said Sr. William Throckmorton for and in Consideration of the some of 75li of lawfull mony of England well and truly before hand payd by the said William Tracy whereof the said Sr. William Throckmorton doth acknowledge the receipt by theis presents And for divers other good causes and considerations him thereunto especially movinge hath given granted assigned and set over And by theis presents doth give grant assigne and set over unto the said William Tracy his executors administrators and assignes All and singuler the interest benefit property and advantage whatsoever which he the said Sr. William Throckmorton nowe hath or by any wayes or meanes whatsoever shall or may have or make of from by or by reason of the said Indenture or of any grant clause covenant sentence or agreement therein contayned eyther for the present or hereafter to come, And also of in and to all and every Article covenant grant and agreement at any tyme heretofore any manner of wayes had or made by or betwene them the said Sr. William Throckmorton Sr. George Yardley Richard Berkley George Thorpe and John Smyth and one John Woodleefe or any some or more of them, And all and whatsoever benefitt profit power authority or advantage that any manner of wayes shall or may or should or might happen accrewe or arise

therby or by reason thereof to him the said Sr. Willm Throkmorton his executors or administrators of these presents were not or had not been had or made. And also all and every share and shares bill or bills of Adventure privilege power jurisdiction lands or Territoryes profits or commodities which the said Sr. Willm Throkmorton hath or may or might hereafter have or pretend to have for or by reason of the same, Together also with the said Indentures and bill or bills of Adventure privilege or endowment. And further the said Sr. Willm Throkmorton doth hereby declare himselfe to be contented and pleased (as far as in him lyeth) That the said Indenture first recyted shall or may be surrendered and a newe to be taken with omission of the name of him the said Sr. Willm Throkmorton as to the said Willm Tracy and the residue of the partners shall be thought fit. And further the said Sr. Willm Throkmorton doth hereby give power and authority to the said Willm Tracy his executors and assignes to aske receive and take for him and in his name to the sole use and benefit of him the said Willm Tracy his executors administrators and assignes All and whatsoever goods merchandizes or profits which either already are arrived or which hereafter shall arrive or come into the kingdom of England from the said land of Virginia, or what is are or shall be in the said land of Virginia wherein the said Sr. Willm is or shall be interested. And further doth hereby grant and assigne to the said Willm Tracy all the benefit advantage and demand which hee the said Sr. Willm any wayes hath or may pretend to have of in or to any servant or servants heretofore sent into Virginia as aforesaid, or of in or to any Indenture or Covenant whereby all or any of such servants are or stand bound to him the said Sr. Willm Joyntly or severally. And finally the said Sr. Willm Throkmorton doth hereby Covenant and promise to doe any other or further Act for the better granting and transferring over to him the said Willm Tracy his executors or assignes all or any thing or things whatsoever herein contained or meant or intended hereby or by reason hereof to be granted transferred covenanted conveyed or [102] contained, or which may arise redowne or come to him by reason of any contract bargain or agreement made by or amongst them the said Sr. Willm Richard George John Smyth and John Woodleefe or any of them or of or by their partnership. And for performance of all and every the said Covenants agreements and promises herein contained the said Sr. Willm Throkmorton bindeth himselfe his executors and administrators to the said Willm Tracy in the

CVIII. Alderman Johnson. A Letter to Sr Edwin Sandys May 16, 1620

Ferrar Papers Document in Magdalene College, Cambridge. Autograph Letter, Signed List of Records No. 173

Wor. Sr I pray you take knowledge, that the base price of ijs the pownd for the magazines sold tobacco, wch I badd the other Daie by the Candle, was intended by me for the Companye hopinge some others would haue owtbidden, but seeing it so fell to my offer, no man biddinge more, and that the Company yesterday confirmed that, at ijs, and the rotten to me at xijd, allthowghe (so god help me) I knowe not what to doe wth it nor wher to sel it yet for as muche as I am deeply ingaged in the Customhowse to the somme of 900li for Impost & Custome and otherwise in bond for the magazine wch by this sele that dayes sale must be discharged and for that the time of free shipping owt expires wthin thes 10 Dayes I am content to accept it and to Adventure it into the streights and so an end of that

As for Mr Caninges as 2°, 57 wch nowe the Company with holds, I cowld wishe he might haue it, being bowght fayrlie by the candle as also fearing, as experience hath tawght us we shall sell it for lesse hear after, if not yet I pray you be a means to let him haue a third of it as the rest shalbe sold, wch is a fayer course and I suppose will well content him and so we shall come allso to righte wth him for that wch he oweth, & so I rest yo' loueing frend

Robt JOHNSON 16 May 1620.

[Indorsed by Sir Edwin Sandys:] Mr Alderman Johnson 16. Maij: 1620. [Addressed by Alderman Johnson:] To the right worll Sr Edwyn Sandes Knight Treasurer for virginia DD.
